title: Is a career in chemistry really worth it? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is no simple answer for that question: what does “really worth it” mean? If you wish to work and study at a well-known university, and succeed in doing so, then you might wish to treat that as an intellectual end unto itself. But if you expect that will open the door to a career in Chemistry, then the job market for well-qualified chemists is already very saturated with…..well-qualified chemists. You might also consider a third pathway, in which a chemistry degree helps, but is not the end-all (e.g., patent lawyers, environmental engineer, etc. To a significant extent, “being a chemist” means having a graduate degree in the field. At the same time, research-lead universities depend on inexpensive graduate students to carry out the laboratory projects of research directors, be teaching assistants for large-enrollment classes and ultimately bring in grant overheads for the universities. They aren’t there to prepare you for the job market, because otherwise they would demonstrate this by providing data on long-term employment outcomes for their graduates. Be warned. Get objective advice.

Well, ask a simple question to yourself, do you like chemistry ? If yes, then it's worth for you and if no then it is not a penny worth if it can't fill your passion. There are many great chemists who have made their career following there passion! You can be one of them too.
